items.standfirst: Israel Calls Up 60,000 Reservists Ahead Of Gaza City Takeover Israeli media is reporting that around 60,000 Israeli reservists are set to receive call-up orders on Wednesday as the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) gear up for a major assault on Gaza City. A report in Times of Israel notes that…

items.title: Israeli military says first stages of assault on Gaza City have begun
items.standfirst: Call-up letters have gone out to 60,000 reservists to bolster an operation which is expected to last until next year.
items.content: Call-up letters have gone out to 60,000 reservists to bolster an operation which is expected to last until next year.

items.title: Israel pounds Gaza, killing 81, as it begins assault to seize Gaza City
items.standfirst: Attacks come as Israeli-induced famine grips the besieged Strip amid calls for Israel to accept a mediated truce.
items.content: Attacks come as Israeli-induced famine grips the besieged Strip amid calls for Israel to accept a mediated truce.

items.title: Israel says it has taken first steps of military operation to seize Gaza City
items.standfirst: Israeli troops clashed with Hamas fighters in Gaza on Wednesday as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office said he was accelerating the military operation to seize Gaza City, the enclave's biggest urban centre, despite international criticism of an assault likely to force the displacement of many more Palestinians.
items.content: Israeli troops clashed with Hamas fighters in Gaza on Wednesday as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office said he was accelerating the military operation to seize Gaza City, the enclave's biggest urban centre, despite international criticism of an assault likely to force the displacement of many more Palestinians.

items.title: Israel begins planned Gaza City assault as it calls up 60,000 reservists

items.content: Israel says it has begun the first stages of its planned assault to seize Gaza City.

items.title: Israel begins first stages of takeover operation - as UK condemns settlement plan
items.standfirst: Israel has said it has begun the first stages of its takeover of Gaza City - as the UK condemned the approval of plans for a new West Bank settlement.
items.content: Israel has said it has begun the first stages of its takeover of Gaza City - as the UK condemned the approval of plans for a new West Bank settlement.

items.title: Israel calls up thousands of reservists as it prepares new Gaza offensive
items.standfirst: Israel will call up 60,000 reservists as it prepares to launch an expanded military operation in Gaza City.
items.content: Israel will call up 60,000 reservists as it prepares to launch an expanded military operation in Gaza City.

items.title: Israel enters first stage of planned assault on Gaza City
items.standfirst: TEL AVIV — Israel entered the first stages of a planned assault on Gaza City on Wednesday after approving a plan to take it over that includes calling up 60,000 reservists for an expanded military operation in the besieged Palestinian enclave.
items.content: TEL AVIV — Israel entered the first stages of a planned assault on Gaza City on Wednesday after approving a plan to take it over that includes calling up 60,000 reservists for an expanded military operation in the besieged Palestinian enclave.

ai_summary: Israel initiated the first stages of its planned assault to seize Gaza City.

Attacks on Gaza City resulted in eighty-one deaths, according to reports.
The UK condemned the approval of plans for a new West Bank settlement.
The operation is expected to last until next year, according to reports.

items.title: Texas House passes GOP redistricting maps to give party five more seats
items.standfirst: The Republican-controlled state House in Texas has passed new congressional maps that aim to pad the party’s majority in Washington by as much as five seats in the midterm elections, a move that comes as battles over redistricting spread across the country.

clusters.title: Brazil’s ex-President Bolsonaro planned asylum in Argentina, police say
clusters.neutral_headline: Brazil Police Claim Bolsonaro Planned Argentina Asylum

items.title: Brazil’s ex-President Bolsonaro planned asylum in Argentina, police say
items.standfirst: Police claim Brazil's ex-President Jair Bolsonaro wrote letter seeking asylum in Argentina amid coup probe.
items.content: Police claim Brazil's ex-President Jair Bolsonaro wrote letter seeking asylum in Argentina amid coup probe.

items.title: Brazil police file court documents accusing Bolsonaro of planning to flee to Argentina to seek asylum
items.standfirst: Brazil’s former president is accused of allegedly plotting a military coup, but he denies the chargesBrazilian police have claimed in court documents that they have found a document on the mobile phone of former president Jair Bolsonaro suggesting he had planned to flee to Argentina ahead of his judgment for allegedly plotting a military coup.The far-right populist is facing a jail term of over 40 years when Brazil’s supreme court convenes next month to decide whether he is guilty of conspiring to overturn the result of the 2022 presidential election, which Bolsonaro lost to his leftwing opponent Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Continue reading...
items.content: Brazil’s former president is accused of allegedly plotting a military coup, but he denies the chargesBrazilian police have claimed in court documents that they have found a document on the mobile phone of former president Jair Bolsonaro suggesting he had planned to flee to Argentina ahead of his judgment for allegedly plotting a military coup.The far-right populist is facing a jail term of over 40 years when Brazil’s supreme court convenes next month to decide whether he is guilty of conspiring to overturn the result of the 2022 presidential election, which Bolsonaro lost to his leftwing opponent Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Continue reading...

items.title: Bolsonaro Mulled ‘Urgent’ Argentina Asylum in Letter, Say Police
Brazilian police accuse Bolsonaro of planning to flee to Argentina and seek asylum
items.standfirst: Brazil’s federal police said that messages found on the telephone of embattled former President Jair Bolsonaro show that at one point he wanted to flee to Argentina and request political asylum, according to documents seen Wednesday by the Associated Press.
items.content: Brazil’s federal police said that messages found on the telephone of embattled former President Jair Bolsonaro show that at one point he wanted to flee to Argentina and request political asylum, according to documents seen Wednesday by the Associated Press.

clusters.title: Appeals court allows DHS to end protected status for migrants from Central America and Nepal
clusters.neutral_headline: Appeals Court Allows End of Migrant Protected Status

items.title: Appeals court allows DHS to end protected status for migrants from Central America and Nepal
items.standfirst: A federal appeals court on Wednesday sided with the Trump administration and halted for now a lower court’s order that had kept in place temporary protections for 60,000 migrants from Central America and Nepal.
items.content: A federal appeals court on Wednesday sided with the Trump administration and halted for now a lower court’s order that had kept in place temporary protections for 60,000 migrants from Central America and Nepal.

items.title: US court allows Trump to end temporary protections for 60,000 migrants
items.standfirst: Appeals court pauses an order that had protected status for Nepalese, Hondurans and Nicaraguans.
items.content: Appeals court pauses an order that had protected status for Nepalese, Hondurans and Nicaraguans.

items.title: US court allows Trump officials to end protected status for 60,000 migrants
items.standfirst: Administration officials given legal right to move towards deportation of people from Nepal, Honduras and NicaraguaA federal appeals court on Wednesday sided with the Trump administration and halted for now a lower court’s order that had kept in place temporary protections for 60,000 migrants from Central America and Nepal.This means that the Republican administration can move toward removing an estimated 7,000 people from Nepal whose temporary protected status designations expired on 5 August. The TPS designations and legal status of 51,000 Hondurans and 3,000 Nicaraguans are set to expire 8 September, at which point they will become eligible for removal. Continue reading...
items.content: Administration officials given legal right to move towards deportation of people from Nepal, Honduras and NicaraguaA federal appeals court on Wednesday sided with the Trump administration and halted for now a lower court’s order that had kept in place temporary protections for 60,000 migrants from Central America and Nepal.This means that the Republican administration can move toward removing an estimated 7,000 people from Nepal whose temporary protected status designations expired on 5 August. The TPS designations and legal status of 51,000 Hondurans and 3,000 Nicaraguans are set to expire 8 September, at which point they will become eligible for removal. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A federal appeals court sided with the Trump administration.
The court halted a lower court's order for migrant protections.
The order had kept temporary protections for 60,000 migrants.
The TPS designations for Nepalese expired on August 5th.
Hondurans and Nicaraguans' TPS designations expire on September 8th.

items.title: Massacres in eastern Congo cast doubt on U.S. mediated peace deal

items.title: At least 140 killed by Rwanda-backed rebels in eastern DR Congo, rights group says
items.standfirst: Human Rights Watch said 141 people, predominantly Hutus, were feared to have been killed in eastern Congo in July in attacks believed to have been carried out by the Rwanda-backed M23 group, the most prominent of the armed groups fighting for control of the region.
items.content: Human Rights Watch said 141 people, predominantly Hutus, were feared to have been killed in eastern Congo in July in attacks believed to have been carried out by the Rwanda-backed M23 group, the most prominent of the armed groups fighting for control of the region.

items.title: DR Congo rebels killed 140 civilians despite peace process, rights group says
items.standfirst: Attacks were carried out in more than a dozen villages last month, Human Rights Watch says.
items.content: Attacks were carried out in more than a dozen villages last month, Human Rights Watch says.

ai_summary: Rwanda-backed rebels killed hundreds of villagers in July.
The attacks occurred in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.
Human Rights Watch reported 141 deaths in the attacks.
The attacks were carried out by the M23 group.
The attacks occurred despite the peace process.

clusters.title: Walmart recalls its frozen shrimp in 13 states, citing potential radioactive contamination
clusters.neutral_headline: Walmart Recalls Shrimp Due to Radioactive Contamination

items.title: Walmart recalls its frozen shrimp in 13 states, citing potential radioactive contamination
Walmart recalls potentially radioactive shrimp sold in 13 US states
items.standfirst: FDA officials detected Cesium-137, a radioactive isotope, in shipping containers and a sample of shrimp from IndonesiaWalmart has recalled frozen, raw shrimp sold in 13 states because federal health officials say it could have potential radioactive contamination.The US Food and Drug Administration asked Walmart to pull three lots of Great Value brand frozen shrimp from stores after federal officials detected Cesium-137, a radioactive isotope, in shipping containers and a sample of breaded shrimp imported from Indonesia. Continue reading...
items.content: FDA officials detected Cesium-137, a radioactive isotope, in shipping containers and a sample of shrimp from IndonesiaWalmart has recalled frozen, raw shrimp sold in 13 states because federal health officials say it could have potential radioactive contamination.The US Food and Drug Administration asked Walmart to pull three lots of Great Value brand frozen shrimp from stores after federal officials detected Cesium-137, a radioactive isotope, in shipping containers and a sample of breaded shrimp imported from Indonesia. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Walmart recalled frozen shrimp from thirteen states.
The recall was due to potential radioactive contamination.
The FDA detected Cesium-137 in shipping containers.
The shrimp was from the Great Value brand.
The shrimp was imported from Indonesia.

items.title: US hits ICC with more sanctions, targets French judge involved in Netanyahu arrest warrant
items.standfirst: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Wednesday announced more sanctions on International Criminal Court judges, saying that the court was a "national security threat" because it had sought to prosecute US or Israeli nationals. Judge Nicolas Guillou of France, who is presiding over a case in which an arrest warrant was issued for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, was among those sanctioned.

clusters.title: Macron denounces Netanyahu’s ‘abject’ claim that he is fueling antisemitism
clusters.neutral_headline: Macron Denounces Netanyahu's Antisemitism Claim

items.title: Macron denounces Netanyahu’s ‘abject’ claim that he is fueling antisemitism
items.standfirst: French President Emmanuel Macron denounced Netanyahu’s remarks as “abject” and “erroneous” in response to Israel Prime Minister’s accusations that his intention to recognize a Palestinian state is fueling antisemitism.
items.content: French President Emmanuel Macron denounced Netanyahu’s remarks as “abject” and “erroneous” in response to Israel Prime Minister’s accusations that his intention to recognize a Palestinian state is fueling antisemitism.

items.title: Macron hits out at ‘abject’ Netanyahu claim of rise in antisemitism in France
items.standfirst: French president responds to Israeli PM’s ‘erroneous’ allegations in relation to decision to recognise state of Palestine Emmanuel Macron has hit out at Benjamin Netanyahu for his “abject” and “erroneous” remarks after Israel’s prime minister claimed that antisemitism had “surged” in France after the country’s decision to recognise a Palestinian state in September.In a statement released late on Tuesday, the office of the French president pushed back against Netanyahu’s claim. “The analysis suggesting that France’s decision to recognise the state of Palestine in September is behind the rise in antisemitic violence in France is erroneous, abject, and will not go unanswered,” it said. “The current period calls for seriousness and responsibility, not generalisation and manipulation.” Continue reading...
items.content: French president responds to Israeli PM’s ‘erroneous’ allegations in relation to decision to recognise state of Palestine Emmanuel Macron has hit out at Benjamin Netanyahu for his “abject” and “erroneous” remarks after Israel’s prime minister claimed that antisemitism had “surged” in France after the country’s decision to recognise a Palestinian state in September.In a statement released late on Tuesday, the office of the French president pushed back against Netanyahu’s claim. “The analysis suggesting that France’s decision to recognise the state of Palestine in September is behind the rise in antisemitic violence in France is erroneous, abject, and will not go unanswered,” it said. “The current period calls for seriousness and responsibility, not generalisation and manipulation.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Emmanuel Macron called Netanyahu's remarks "abject" and "erroneous".
Netanyahu claimed that recognizing a Palestinian state fueled antisemitism.
Macron's office stated the analysis was erroneous and would be addressed.
The French president's office responded to the Israeli Prime Minister's accusations.
The French government decided to recognize the state of Palestine in September.

clusters.title: At least 78 people killed as bus collides with fuel truck in western Afghanistan

items.title: At least 78 people killed as bus collides with fuel truck in western Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Children among dead after bus carrying Afghans deported from Iran crashed and caught fire in Herat province Seventy-eight people have died in western Afghanistan in a collision between a bus carrying Afghans who had recently been deported from Iran and two other vehicles.The bus hit a motorcycle and a truck transporting fuel on Tuesday night, causing an explosive fire in Guzara district, Herat province. Two of the three survivors later died of their injuries, officials said on Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Children among dead after bus carrying Afghans deported from Iran crashed and caught fire in Herat province Seventy-eight people have died in western Afghanistan in a collision between a bus carrying Afghans who had recently been deported from Iran and two other vehicles.The bus hit a motorcycle and a truck transporting fuel on Tuesday night, causing an explosive fire in Guzara district, Herat province. Two of the three survivors later died of their injuries, officials said on Wednesday. Continue reading...

items.content: At least 75 people, including 17 children, have been killed in Afghanistan in a traffic accident involving a bus carrying migrants who were deported from Iran, officials said Wednesday.

items.title: Air Canada flight attendants reach ‘tentative’ deal with airline to end strike
items.standfirst: Strike over wages and ground work has cancelled travel for 500,000 people worldwideAir Canada flight attendants say they have reached a “tentative” deal with the airline to end a strike over wages and ground work that has cancelled travel for half a million people worldwide.Roughly 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job after midnight Saturday, insisting Air Canada had failed to address their demands for higher pay and compensation for unpaid ground work, including during boarding. Continue reading...
items.content: Strike over wages and ground work has cancelled travel for 500,000 people worldwideAir Canada flight attendants say they have reached a “tentative” deal with the airline to end a strike over wages and ground work that has cancelled travel for half a million people worldwide.Roughly 10,000 flight attendants walked off the job after midnight Saturday, insisting Air Canada had failed to address their demands for higher pay and compensation for unpaid ground work, including during boarding. Continue reading...

items.title: Air Canada and flight attendants reach tentative deal to end strike
items.standfirst: The Air Canada strike has ended after flight attendants reached a tentative agreement with the airline, both parties said early Tuesday."The Strike has ended," the Canadian Union of Public Employees said in a Facebook post advising its membership to "fully cooperate with resumption of operations."
items.content: The Air Canada strike has ended after flight attendants reached a tentative agreement with the airline, both parties said early Tuesday."The Strike has ended," the Canadian Union of Public Employees said in a Facebook post advising its membership to "fully cooperate with resumption of operations."

ai_summary: Air Canada flight attendants reached a tentative deal with the airline.
The deal aims to end a strike over wages and ground work.
The strike had canceled travel for approximately 500,000 people.
Roughly 10,000 flight attendants participated in the strike.
The Canadian Union of Public Employees announced the strike's end.
